reviewText:
Overview
AGoW is tailored for people who were into the classic 16-bit/32-bit JSRPG era. With multiple difficulties, paths to choose from and new game+ it has a decent replay value despite it's initial time sink".

Pro & Con Points
The Combat System is AGoW's strong point with an array of skills and combos to perform. You can create powerful characters and do insane combos through the link system that can take down hardest encounters easily if executed right.

The mid point would be the Story
date: Crafting System and Adventure Guild Rewards. While the story is typical
recommended: choosing your mate and alignment makes for an ineresting twist to keep you interested. The Crafting System allows you create & upgrade powerful equipment that gives you a clear edge in battles. The Adventure Guild rewards you based on your acheivements in battle and Item/currency accumulation.\n\nThe Weak point of this game is the "Time" required to fully enjoy all the game has to offer. AGoW can take anywhere from 40 to 60 hours to complete on a generic play through. To delve deeper can run you in excess of 80 to 100 hours. Many people not familiar with this genre will be immediately turned off by this."

reviewText: To be honest this game is only, ok. I reccomend it to those who are fans of anime, JRPG's, and strategic combat all at the same level, if not steer clear. It has the typical anime story of a guy who must save the world, but in this one he must give the souls of his children to a mysterious deity, which is kinda cool, so needless to say you must choose between a set of girls that you want to have a kid with, be forwarned that whichever girl you choose will also affect the kids starting skills and weapon, so choose wisely. I also want to point out that if you get this game on steam, do not add any of the extra pp to your characters at the beggining of the game, it will make you too OP and the game will be no fun. THIS GAME IS HARD FOR THE UNINTELLIGENT, if you play western RPG's where all you do is press X to win i.e. all new final fantasy games, then you will be frustrated at first. This game takes a lot of math skills and memorization of your characters movements, placements, magic and attack power, hit chance, skills and skill combinations between allies and themselves, but as soon as you figure out who needs to be where for each enemy you will feel like a peasant who became a king.

reviewText:
Good solo game with good story, characters, mechanics, replayability, and depth. But very alienating interface and a lack of manual pose problems.

It has a crafting system and a creature system, both of which give decent motivations for grinding. It has the usual JRPG style leveling system for heroes, meaning that they don't all share levels and you have to make up your mind about which 6 characters out of the 32 to use. It has an achievement system with some rewards, and these too will keep you busy. The morality system is unusual to western audience as it rewards neutrality, more so than being light/dark. There is also a secret ending that opens up a whole new act - somewhat resembling the endgame" in certain MMOs.

There is an Agarest Wiki
date: as well as a dedicated page at GameFaq. Both pages are compulsory for a good experience. Starting the game on hard mode is recommended; doing so without a guide is not. This is due to the lack of manual more than anything else.\n\nThis game passes the Bechdel test
recommended: but all five protagonists are male. There is a "6th protagonist" who is female
hoursPlayed: but you'll have to unlock the secret ending."

reviewText:
This is one of the few JRPG's that I have enjoyed in past years.  First lets start with the good:
-Submersive storyline, additional story is added frequently enough to keep you interested.
-Tactical combat, you actually have to think about each battle.
-Humorous text echanges between characters.
-Not too easy not too hard (and there are multiple difficulty settings).
-Cool combinations of skills that make you want to try different tactics.

Now lets talk about the bad:
-You have to place your characters around the tiles EACH battle, and there are MANY battles, it may not seem like much, but it got really repetitive for me.
-Game starts you off with extremely over-powered items that allows you to trail-blaze through the first two parts of the game.
-Fighting the same monsters with new skins gets a little boring.
-Each square you move on the Act I-V map has a new battle to be fought, and they start to last a very long time in the later acts, making it seem that you are getting nowhere.
-Bosses dont scale very well in the game, some seem to be ridiculously difficult, while others are a pushover.

With that being said, I would reccomend this game to my friends, but I would suggest playing the game on Easy so you can actually make it all the way through without getting bored.  I would reccomend Normal or hard only to players who want to have a challenge and are willing to go through the tedious battles.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
This game is so bad it's good. If you are a die hard JRPG fan that enjoys comedy and poorly vieled innuendo, this game is for you.

The bad: After a few battles, the battles themselves become dry, bland, and repetitive. Lots of dialoge that you have to press a button to advance. Cut scenes would have been nice for the endless dialogue. Smithing decent weapons, armor, is a pain. Battle graphics are pretty meh as well.

The good: This is an RPG across generations. At  critical moments you woo female companions that ultimately you father the next generation of hero with. Your choices have consequences on the future. Combo hits, wrecking faces, chaining hits together. Setting up the battle field is an exercise in strategy and planning.

Despite the obvious flaws with the game and the repetition in battles and low budget quality this game would be worth picking up if you can get it for 5-10 dollars or less.

reviewText:
I find it hard to believe this was a PS3 title and not PS2. It's fairly simple compared to its 360 Record of Agarest Wars, but I wasn't expecting the gap in quality to be this big, at least in characterization.

This really plays on all the stereotypes pretty hard. Though that is essentially the routine in these RRPGs and I LOVE Record of Agarest Wars dearly, but this game doesn't do much outside of the archtypes it picks for each character personality. For my it isn't a turn off so much, it sticks to the formula to a T. Well update as I unlock more characters.

This game if going to be a hit or miss for many, though I highly recommend you pick it up for the price alone, the ability BREAK of combining two or more moves to create a uniqie ART ability that deals insane damage is a lot of fun, very Phantasy Star 4 only you don't need to organized your whole party to do these.

Game is actually fun and all the actual relevant game content is included in the base game, despite the company's silly labeling of 95 dollars would of DLC that is nothing but for those too impatient to play the actual game. The 'Bonus' Dungeons 1-5 and such are offered FREE of charge with rest being items that can be unlocked through gameplay itself for the most part.

If you like games like Makai Kingdom, Growlancer (god that game needs a steam release), and dating sims, this is a pretty good start. Maybe I should of said Final Fantasy Tactics and Disgaea for those less familiar with the first two I mentioned, but if you catch this game on a 50% of more sale, you might find it an interesting mix of genre of a game worth your time if you're willing.

I paid full price for it and I have no regrets so far. It doesn't add to the archtypes, but it doesn't stray away from them either, characters are cute and generally likable. It's really hit or miss and I would only recommend this title to people who are into turned based JRPGs.

Just please don't compare this one to Record of Agarest Wars, this title here is very generic but it is by no means a bad game because of it. I only hope Ghostlight will bring over Record of Agarest Wars to Steam as well, this series certainly is very underrated and even this title will grow on you as you play.

I cannot stress this enough, do not expect grade A dialogue, the narratives are amazing, the story itself is good, but the characters are generic, if not for the very talented and pleasing to listen to VAs who took a bland script and added much life into these cookie cutter personalities.


Gameplay 6.5/10
Difficulty Balance 10/10 Does not affect the story, so unless you're like me and go for challenge with your story, so choosing Normal or Easy will not punish you.

It's worth the price for me, and I hope you give it a try and help how support to Ghostlight to bring over more of their more recent titles!

reviewText: So I remember Final Fantasy Tactics and the immersive story that was offered by Square-Enix at hat time. This gam in many ways has a battle system very similar to chess, and the time one must put into this game can be exorbitant and rewarding. Why the Metascore critic rated this so low is beyond me. Any RPG fan knows you have to invest time into the game itself, and if the game demands that time then the outcomes are very rewarding in the end. The game itself is pretty amazing taking us back to an over-simplified system that is easy to use. Sure the graphics might seem cheesy by today's standards, but the story is as complex as the great Greek myths. If you want a story-line based game, then this is what you have been searching for all along!

reviewText:
Overall a good game, especially when killing time, or simply have nothing to do.

Agarest is a strategy (RPG) game, so be warned, some may like it and some may not. I don't mind it as I've played lots of strategy RPG games before, and this game reminds me of a game I use to play back when I was younger (Golden Sun) even though it wasn't a strategy RPG game.

[PROS]
-The game isn't just a click, click, click. It also spices it up by giving different elements into it., like the exploration mode. Where you actually take control of the characters and explore places, such as caves. However the detailing may make it hard at first where you can and can't go when in exploration mode, but you'll soon get to pick it up.
-There are also tons of combos that you could do with each different members of your party.
-5 different stories, with MANY different outcomes depending on your decision making! (read outline for a brief summary of what I mean, hopefully you understand)
-Collect different special books to unlock rare weapons and armours from the blacksmith.

[CONS]
-Graphics may be off-putting for people.
-Strategy Role-Playing Game may not appeal to you.

Definitely give it a thought of buying :)
However, since I pre-purchased it, I got a some special DLC's for free, and there were some that improved abilities and gave weapons, which were a bit OP (overpowered) in beggining games ^^ but it does wither away because you'll need to upgrade it in time.

-Outline-
5 Generations; 5 story lines
Depending on who you marry, the hero for the next generation will have certain abilities and characteristics.
During the stories, you'll get to make decisions and these decisions effect your path and also your mindset (light or dark) and will affect which girl will be affectious towards you.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
Traditional J-RPG is not for everyone.

The genre is targeted towards players who would (and could) spend around 300 hours in it (most of it simply ... grinding).

Luckily, the otakus have provided a wiki so you won't be raging through the process of grinding for the wrong items... or unlocking the gallery (Google/Bing it).

That said, I took some shortcuts around in this game with the DLCs. From those items in the DLCs, your gameplay will be easy mode until chapter 3... Then the grinding begins.

The 2D art is fine, although I dislike the pixelated models (High-res mod anyone?) on my 21inch monitor.

As for the story... the story is a typical fantasy setup with elves, orcs, multiple gods, the characters roles in them, etc. Nothing too unique, but with Anime twist.

6/10 Passable, Not worth the full price.

You can get it if it is on sale AND you have tons of free time on your hand.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText: If you can get past (or even enjoy) the cringeworthy dialogue and harem aspects of this game, you'll find an enjoyable turn based stragtegy JRPG. There is a lot of depth to the combat, and pulling off multi-character combos can be satisfying. For combos character positioning is very important. Out of combat you'll find a lot to do including crafting/upgrading weapons and armor, changing out skills, learning new skills, and it goes on. However the game does get very repetitive, forcing you to complete the same exact battle multiple times before you can proceed to the next event/dungeon. The battle maps themselves are very bare, with no terrain to speak of, and they are rehashed way too often. The plot is nothing to write home about. Character interactions are forgettable at best, and cringeworthy at worst (Except maybe for Winfield, he has his moments.)\n\nA decent game that is definitely worth getting if on sale, and you can ignore the DLC (which is just a bunch of early game breaking set of items.) Just don't expect something that's on par with a game like Final Fantasy Tactics.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText: I do not feel like Metacritic gave this game enough credit, and as I play the game I find myself becoming more entranced with Agarest's story. For me, I felt like this game was on the gameplay style of Final Fantasy, yet it gives its own unique perspective on RPG's. The fact that there are multiple generation lines that are affected by your own choices (between your path of light and dark, and choice of affection with certain characters, something I was unsure of at first but grew very fond of in the end) makes this game versatile and worth playing over again (trying to see what the other options would hold to as their stories progress). This game gets my vote for a game that RPG enthusiasts should check out and play through at LEAST a couple of times to gain that diversity of character outcomes. I even went and picked up the Xbox 360 prequel" to this game and once I finish the PC game will be looking at that one as well. Top game I've played to date for sure"

reviewText: So I remember Final Fantasy Tactics and the immersive story that was offered by Square-Enix at hat time. This gam in many ways has a battle system very similar to chess, and the time one must put into this game can be exorbitant and rewarding. Why the Metascore critic rated this so low is beyond me. Any RPG fan knows you have to invest time into the game itself, and if the game demands that time then the outcomes are very rewarding in the end. The game itself is pretty amazing taking us back to an over-simplified system that is easy to use. Sure the graphics might seem cheesy by today's standards, but the story is as complex as the great Greek myths. If you want a story-line based game, then this is what you have been searching for all along!

reviewText:
Overall a good game, especially when killing time, or simply have nothing to do.

Agarest is a strategy (RPG) game, so be warned, some may like it and some may not. I don't mind it as I've played lots of strategy RPG games before, and this game reminds me of a game I use to play back when I was younger (Golden Sun) even though it wasn't a strategy RPG game.

[PROS]
-The game isn't just a click, click, click. It also spices it up by giving different elements into it., like the exploration mode. Where you actually take control of the characters and explore places, such as caves. However the detailing may make it hard at first where you can and can't go when in exploration mode, but you'll soon get to pick it up.
-There are also tons of combos that you could do with each different members of your party.
-5 different stories, with MANY different outcomes depending on your decision making! (read outline for a brief summary of what I mean, hopefully you understand)
-Collect different special books to unlock rare weapons and armours from the blacksmith.

[CONS]
-Graphics may be off-putting for people.
-Strategy Role-Playing Game may not appeal to you.

Definitely give it a thought of buying :)
However, since I pre-purchased it, I got a some special DLC's for free, and there were some that improved abilities and gave weapons, which were a bit OP (overpowered) in beggining games ^^ but it does wither away because you'll need to upgrade it in time.

-Outline-
5 Generations; 5 story lines
Depending on who you marry, the hero for the next generation will have certain abilities and characteristics.
During the stories, you'll get to make decisions and these decisions effect your path and also your mindset (light or dark) and will affect which girl will be affectious towards you.

reviewText: I'm not really sure if I recommend this game. It seems to be pretty good, but I'm already bored of it. The mechanics seem to be very in-depth, but the execution is really strange. Right off the bat, my characters have looted such crazy items that make them almost invulnerable. There's no real challenge, or thought out strategy for building up your character into a complete bad-♥♥♥. You start off a bad-♥♥♥, and I'm not sure that's really such a good thing. I like the slow buildup, being challenged along the way, and culminating into an epic battle to finish off the game. However, I've played through a considerable amount and have found no interest in the story, and the fights hold no challenge. It's fun and all, but I feel like there are better games out there at around the same price-point.

reviewText:
Agarest: Generations of War is both frustrating and fun. The battles are all usually the same except for occasional variety, the story line (Dialogue I meant) is pathetic, the relationship gauge is entirely stupid, but the combat itself (if you get used to repetition) is quite entertaining. It encourages strategic thinking and placement and if you make a mistake, its repricussions are usually dire. I have not played this game on easy or normal mode, just skipped those and went straight to hard mode because man mode. The DLC weapons and items are 100% a waste of money unless one wants to breeze through the whole game, and using only silver weapons for a good amout of Generation ONE is so frustratingly challenging(Silver Sword trick gives lots of them :|). If you want a challenge and do not mind the same format of battle for over 1000 little skirmishes (by the way 1000 is probably not even close to how many of these there are. More I'd guess) while constantly having the enemy get stronger and stronger then this game is definitely for you.

reviewText:
Long review incoming. If you just want to see my score and pros / cons of this game, skip to the end.

Agarest: Generations of War is a tactical JRPG (Japanese Role Playing Game). Being a JRPG, you should be prepared for severe grinding at times, especially if playing in highest difficulty level. The free DLC that come with the game can ease up the beginning, but the gear won't last through the whole game and there is little you can do about it but grind for levels and better gear. On the third generation, things start getting tougher. Having ignored some of the game mechanics during the first two generations, depending on my superior equipment and characters who continue with you between generations, I was stuttered when I was thrown in a game-over-hell nearing the end of third generation.

The story begins when a young man, Leonhardt, leads a small unit to conquer more land for his king. Leonhardt wonders if he is doing the right thing and betrays his king when he saves a young elf girl from his own men. A dark knight arrives, mortally wounding Leonhardt, but not finishing him off. Before he passes away, Leonhardt is visited by a mysterious woman who saves his life and grants him the power to fight against the darkness, but at a price: he must eventually sacrifice himself as a Spirit Vessel" to seal the great pillar in the land

reviewText:
There is a lot of good and bad to this game. You're going to get a ton of hours out of it, which means your time/money ratio is going to be pretty good. However, the combat becomes repetitive, and it can become tedious at times. Personally I had to drop it for a while, then come back and play some more a few months later. The crafting in this game is ridiculous, and not in a good way. It becomes very complicated to make basic items, and you’re often either stuck grinding for pieces, or getting creamed in battle later on, not to mention that the game doesn’t do a good job of explaining how exactly the crafting/upgrading works. Crafting is, by far, the worst part of this game, second place going to repetitive combat.
Now that the bad is out of the way, there are definitely redeeming aspects to this game. The art is done anime-esque, but it’s done well, and all of the characters look very unique. The backstory itself is pretty basic, (hero, destiny, destroy evil) but the game really puts an interesting spin on it by making it multi-generational. The cast itself is also diverse, and much of the story is character driven over plot driven, and you see characters develop, especially each of the three women for each generation, the more you interact with them and progress. While on the subject of the women, yes, there are some ecchi moments, but it is nowhere near overwhelming or abundant, so don’t let that dissuade you in your choice to purchase it. The combat, while repetitive, can also be fun. The goal to break enemies, get higher combos to earn more TP, and do massive damage to gain titles, adds a fun side aspect to the fight. Also, combos are pretty cool, as you can combine moves together to make more powerful moves, and some of them just look awesome, though after you do it 50 times, the wonder starts to wear off. However, this does encourage you to use more than just your same five characters, so you can expound upon your combos.
All in all, while not perfect, I think this game is for sure worth the buy. As it stands, I’m really enjoying myself, even if I do need to take another break soon. The replay value is also high, as there are choices you can make story wise, and with the women (which transverses into the stats and weapons of your next generation hero, and not just how they look.)
I would also recommend using the DLC that comes with it on your first play through, so you can really figure out what you’re doing, though that’s totally up to you.
Rank: 7.5/10

reviewText:
Only been playing for a few hours so far but already it's certainly fulfilling my expectations.
Proper JRPG action, loads of stats and menus, cutesy characters and graphics, effects, proper japanese VA, great isometric battles - what's not to like?!

I was going to get Zero first but figured I'd do this one as it was the starting point for the series - (as far as I know) - I was looking for a decent JRPG and I'm really glad I found one.
So far the storyline is panning out nicely and even the fact that it's more-or-less On rails" is really refreshing after the last couple of years of wandering around in openworld games
date:
just nice to get back to basics in that regard.

Definitely enthusiastic about finishing and definitely planning on getting Zero.
If you're looking for a good JSRPG with a fun plot and all the trimmings

reviewText: A really interesting JRPG,  It has a lot of things going on in it and a TON of potential playtime.  You could easily play the game for 100+ hours and still not finish the campaign.  Its got a fire emblem kind of feel to the combat system, but it adds on to the basic system and adds loads of combos and skills.  You can capture most of the monsters in the game and use them as playable characters.  There is a very slight dating sim aspect to the game, but its kind of fitting in a JRPG,  In almost every JRPG there are always multiple girls who like your main character, but this game just lets you choose who you actually end up with.  I really wasn't bothered by it.   There really is an insane amount of things going on in the game, If you like JRPGs this is definitely worth a look.

reviewText:
There is a lot of good and bad to this game. You're going to get a ton of hours out of it, which means your time/money ratio is going to be pretty good. However, the combat becomes repetitive, and it can become tedious at times. Personally I had to drop it for a while, then come back and play some more a few months later. The crafting in this game is ridiculous, and not in a good way. It becomes very complicated to make basic items, and you’re often either stuck grinding for pieces, or getting creamed in battle later on, not to mention that the game doesn’t do a good job of explaining how exactly the crafting/upgrading works. Crafting is, by far, the worst part of this game, second place going to repetitive combat.
Now that the bad is out of the way, there are definitely redeeming aspects to this game. The art is done anime-esque, but it’s done well, and all of the characters look very unique. The backstory itself is pretty basic, (hero, destiny, destroy evil) but the game really puts an interesting spin on it by making it multi-generational. The cast itself is also diverse, and much of the story is character driven over plot driven, and you see characters develop, especially each of the three women for each generation, the more you interact with them and progress. While on the subject of the women, yes, there are some ecchi moments, but it is nowhere near overwhelming or abundant, so don’t let that dissuade you in your choice to purchase it. The combat, while repetitive, can also be fun. The goal to break enemies, get higher combos to earn more TP, and do massive damage to gain titles, adds a fun side aspect to the fight. Also, combos are pretty cool, as you can combine moves together to make more powerful moves, and some of them just look awesome, though after you do it 50 times, the wonder starts to wear off. However, this does encourage you to use more than just your same five characters, so you can expound upon your combos.
All in all, while not perfect, I think this game is for sure worth the buy. As it stands, I’m really enjoying myself, even if I do need to take another break soon. The replay value is also high, as there are choices you can make story wise, and with the women (which transverses into the stats and weapons of your next generation hero, and not just how they look.)
I would also recommend using the DLC that comes with it on your first play through, so you can really figure out what you’re doing, though that’s totally up to you.

reviewText: I bought this game because I'm a big fan of turn based strategy and JRPGs. While I was expecting an experience similar to Vandal Hearts, the battle system in this is actually quite different due to combos and lack of counter attacks. While I'm starting to catch on to the combo system, I've discovered you don't necessarily want to move your characters in direct confrontation with the enemies. Instead, you should link them (look for a glowing arc between their heads), overkill the first enemy, and all of your players will all move during this combo to a formation that better favors a follow up attack on subsequent enemies. Although the special effects are awesome, the battles get repetative and even in the premium edition, the battle field is the same grid with few variations in background (usually just the same forest). Also, the equipment included in the additional packs included with the base game make every battle (at least in the beginning of the game) pointlessly easy and unchalleging. The plot isn't entirely original but is well thought out enough to keep the game interesting. There's no actual animation of the characters, just a few different still stances with interchangable facial expressions similar to the animation style in Sakura Spirit. At least the images are crisp, well drawn, and hi-res. The sound fits well with the game. Overall, I would give it an 7.5/10 and only recommend it if you're a die-hard fan of these types of games and it's on sale.

reviewText: I really enjoyed Agarest. I have never played a RPG like Agarest, and for me it turned out pretty good! I like the characters a lot, mainly because they look like characters from an anime. They are well built characters and have plenty of work put into them.\nI love the combat system! The story is good, and the game over all is fun! Its got characters that you will like and ones you won't, and during a generation, you have to choose one of three girls, to start your second generation with, depending on who you choose, and the skills you put on them, will make your son strong or weak. I highly recommend this game and if your a fan of JRPG's or RPG's in general, you will really like this game. One more thing, don't base this game on its Metascore, the people at Metacritic don't know how good this game really is!

reviewText: I am a hardcore fan of this game. Played games like these during my childhood and frankly helped me rekindle old times. I originally played this on the Xbox 360 and Ps3 console versions before switching over here. I always loved how we get the choices in every dating sim and the heroines. The choices we have and the usual fun we have with the service in it. What I loved about this game was the endings and the choices for the kids. This game reminded me when I first picked it up a little bit on par to some of Star Ocean, Growlanser, Ar Tonelico, and many other RPGs I've played that included an ending and possible romance route. What I enjoyed quite greatly was the fact that we have in here the grid system in which has been used before like in disgaea. Obviously the link system was a nice mix when combining moves. I remember spending hours rushing through the other areas and taking one route to see all different approaches to it and multiple saves. What I truly enjoyed this game was as usual the new game+ mode where it transfers over. Having the ability to capture monsters with merciful strike also helped and fusing them. Ah I cannot wait to see more from this series. I love it when they make quite the grand appeal. I obviously love many things but wiith great enthusiasm and experience from both consoles LIMITED Edition as well as the ones after this one, that it is worth the buy. You gotta put some time into it but the fact you have auto battle helps it out but don't forget you still gotta click over it's not like a speed through for those who usually think I will just have them auto level. The weapons you make and accessories have extra moves and the fact that you can use some of those moves to help your character with it's abilities although it is tedious like using a fire element skill multiple times just to upgrade one state. However I must state that as usual for the fun and love of Winfield! HOT SPRINGS/Onsen! A must for any generation.Truly this game really etches in a great memory for me.

reviewText:
Think of it as a middling visual novel (non eroge), and with the least good SRPG I've played smashed into it. Kinda like that Divinity dragon commander thing recently which was basically the same thing but with RTS gameplay. . . .I personally like this better, the gameplay isn't as out-right BAD as dragon commander's was, and the story is more interesting to me, tho I can't honestly call it better (in fact, pretty sure it's worse).

All in all, if you are willing to put the time in, you could really do a lot worse.

Play it without cheating, on hard mode (that means no dlc packs) and see how much fun you can squeeze out of the combat, or just give up on enjoying that clunky, slow, needlessly small-mapped and simple mess and take the dlc (tho cheatengine can give you the same ****, just as early, for free, because it's already in the damn game) and steamroll thro every battle to get to the next darn bit of story.

Either way really.Worth the price of admittion.

And, I've only finished gen 1 thus far. I'll assume the post-game dungeon is pretty cool and that I'll have some extra fun there for now, and just edit this if that doesn't prove to be true. So if my hours played are above 40, then that'll let you know :P.

reviewText:
This game is pretty much your typical SRPG.
It might not be the best game out there but it's worth a try.

The battle system is enjoyable but can be a bit confusing at first. I think there should be more explanation on how the game works.

Aside from that, some battles can be quite annoying because of the difficulty spikes, especially when you reach generation 3, where enemies suddenly start to evade all you attacks and deal more damage.

The story and characters are interesting and there's also many differents paths you can follow.

I would recommend this game to the hardcore jrpg fans and people with lots of free time on their hands, since this one can be quite tricky at times, even on the easy difficulty level.

Although this game is not my favorite, I'm happy they decided to bring the whole series to pc. Now they just need to bring disgaea or persona to steam too :p

reviewText: I bought this game because I'm a big fan of turn based strategy and JRPGs. While I was expecting an experience similar to Vandal Hearts, the battle system in this is actually quite different due to combos and lack of counter attacks. While I'm starting to catch on to the combo system, I've discovered you don't necessarily want to move your characters in direct confrontation with the enemies. Instead, you should link them (look for a glowing arc between their heads), overkill the first enemy, and all of your players will all move during this combo to a formation that better favors a follow up attack on subsequent enemies. Although the special effects are awesome, the battles get repetative and even in the premium edition, the battle field is the same grid with few variations in background (usually just the same forest). Also, the equipment included in the additional packs included with the base game make every battle (at least in the beginning of the game) pointlessly easy and unchalleging. The plot isn't entirely original but is well thought out enough to keep the game interesting. There's no actual animation of the characters, just a few different still stances with interchangable facial expressions similar to the animation style in Sakura Spirit. At least the images are crisp, well drawn, and hi-res. The sound fits well with the game. Overall, I would give it an 7.5/10 and only recommend it if you're a die-hard fan of these types of games and it's on sale.

reviewText: This game is pretty fun. It is easier than most strategy games once you figure out how to do combined attacks. I just do the same attack every battle and win easily. This is the only game I ever pre-ordered and I bought 1 copy for myself and one for my brother. I thought I was getting a deal since it was discounted and came with the DLC that was advertised to come free with the pre-order as if it wasn't something that every player would get free anyway. The DLC comes with the game anyway and you need to turn it off to have a decent experience with this game. It is way too powerful and I just turned it all off to start with, but they released more and auto-enabled it into my game... Also, don't buy any extra DLC. It is all stuff you get in the game anyway and will make everything too easy. I would definely buy this game for $12. It was still a good buy when i got it for $16 since I had been waiting forever for a tactics style game on the PC. This is similar to FFT, Disgaea, and Fire Emblem. It is just as easy as FFT and Disgeae but more repetitive than both with every battle being almost the same. Some great features that make this game much more playable than those other games are the option to skip animations and a setting in the ini file to speed the game up as fast as you want. I like how they keep changing your main character as you go through the chapters so you get to play lots of characters. There are some that you get to keep and you can bring the old ones back if you want, but it is nice not just having one main character that you play the whole game. I found the story to be pretty funny so far. ALL of the female images in the game are sugestive, but if you unlock the CG images, you will find that they are pretty hilarious although I'm sure they were intended to be sexy. Could just be my humor. Don't expect a serious story and you'll have a great time with this game.

Yes there is a ton of expensive dlc, but they are only optional weapon or item upgrades, not content required to get the full experience of the game.\nIf you are comparing this game to classics like FFT, Front Mission, or other strategy-jrpgs, you may be disappointed as Agarest is not trying to be the greatest game ever.  And you know what, that is okay, it satisfies an itch of wanting to play jrpgs on PC, and because of that, it's a pretty decent game.  Nothing special but games don't have to be special to be great.  Give it a try when it goes on sale.

reviewText:
You rike Fire Emblem or similar games such as Ogre Tactics or Final Fantasy Tactics Advance? Go get this game, or you bring such SHAMEFUR DISPLAY to family.

DLC? Not worth it. The base is good enough as it is. The game format is in the Strategy Turn-Based Tile JRPG game. Also, the DLC may NEVER be discounted. As of this review, this thing is on a holiday sale, but NONE of the DLC is discounted, and it's really just getting more points to shave off some grinding. No biggie, please ignore.

Voice acting is alright, it won't win any oscars. But it's not downright horrible. If you're THAT interested in the voiceovers, you can buy the additional voice packs for $9.99. That's the only DLC I'd recommend. The appeal to the story is that you have multiple generations and you can date various people over time. Waifu simulator in a JRPG? Check.

Chaining character attacks, overlimits, and combos is crucial to the game's core mechanic. I only wish there would be an option to SPEED it up faster. Since this game is a port of a console, playing it with your 360 or PS3 controller works well here. Mouse and Keyboard is accessible, you can change the bindings as well, which is a positive.

How does it stand overall?  It's a different take from what you'd get with a game like Disgaea. It gets a bit grindy, but it takes quite some time to get into the bulk of the game, as well as the story. Of course, there's New Game+ and all that jazz, so time is NO issue.

Glorious Nippons and JRPG Strategy Enthusiast, please check this out right away.
Anyone else? If you're comfortable staring at anime pictures as your avatars and like a different taste of a turn-based strategy game, put it on your back burner.

Otherwise? It's average at most, and it will not definitely catch people's short attention span. It's a niche for what it is. If you're more into the western market and want a thrilling experience within the same genre, go take a look at XCON: Enemy Unknown + Enemy WIthin DLC instead as that's more engaging than this game. But for the very few who want another Strategy JRPG in a buried gem, it's worth at least the 10$, or 11.99$ for a Holiday/Flash Sale.

reviewText:
First off, here's a short list of games I would recommend over this that is reasonably within the same genre: Fire emblem (any one), Loren the Amazon princess, Hyperdimension Neptunia (2 + Victory) and Final Fantasy 7.

I did not enjoy this game, and here's why:

The combat is slowly paced and gets boring really quickly, it has some neat ideas but I ended up doing almost exactly the same thing each round because I found something that worked for me. Once you've gotten your head around the tile system, combat becomes pretty easy and more of a chore.

The combat animation is a nice sprite based one, but the character cutouts standing around in the scenes aren't great.

And the talking scenes, drag on forever plus they're terribly translated. It's very obviously japanese. The story is a cliché but not a bad one, and I could live with it if the characters were more interesting. Which they aren't. You've seen these guys before and better.

All in all I just found it boring and unfulfilling and after reaching generation 2 of 5 after 20 hours of stale gameplay and tedious item micromanagement I just plain didn't want to play this game.

I've seen other games do the same thing better, I've seen games turn around after a long time and become good, and I think I gave this the benefit of the doubt.

reviewText:
Agarest: Generations of War is the 3rd game in the series and the first JRPG/VN that I have ever bought (not my first period, first PURCHASED). The story is great and the setting is original. The only other game that has a story  almost as unique as this one is Star Ocean.

Characters archtypes are the usual and typical kind, but it doesn't make the game any less fun.

Its battle style is nothing that I have ever encountered before. Movement and character placement is almost like a game of chess, requiring strategy during movement and battles with your pieces having a preset placement, and knowing your pieces' abilities when attacking can be beneficial to taking out the enemy. If you enjoy chess you'll enjoy this game.

I preordered the game and got all the DLC free. As the frist game that I have ever gotten DLC for (in the beginning of the game), and I find it to break the game. It makes it absolutely no fun. I had to turn it off to enjoy the adventure part. Running through a game completely invincible is next to pointless unless its after you completed the game. Get the DLC after you complete it.

reviewText:
First off, here's a short list of games I would recommend over this that is reasonably within the same genre: Fire emblem (any one), Loren the Amazon princess, Hyperdimension Neptunia (2 + Victory) and Final Fantasy 7.

I did not enjoy this game, and here's why:

The combat is slowly paced and gets boring really quickly, it has some neat ideas but I ended up doing almost exactly the same thing each round because I found something that worked for me. Once you've gotten your head around the tile system, combat becomes pretty easy and more of a chore.

The combat animation is a nice sprite based one, but the character cutouts standing around in the scenes aren't great.

And the talking scenes, drag on forever plus they're terribly translated. It's very obviously japanese. The story is a cliché but not a bad one, and I could live with it if the characters were more interesting. Which they aren't. You've seen these guys before and better.

All in all I just found it boring and unfulfilling and after reaching generation 2 of 5 after 20 hours of stale gameplay and tedious item micromanagement I just plain didn't want to play this game.

I've seen other games do the same thing better, I've seen games turn around after a long time and become good, and I think I gave this the benefit of the doubt.

reviewText: The game is suprisingly good.  It's not the best jrpg but there are few options on PC (at least legally), this game is one of those options.   The game has a surprising amount of content for the price you pay.  The combat is addicting as it is more cerberal than just simple button presses as you must try to find the right positions to link together attacks.   There is a dating sim element in choosing your partner but it is not too risque,  it shows  less than games such as Dragon Age or Mass Effect.   Yes there is a ton of expensive dlc, but they are only optional weapon or item upgrades, not content required to get the full experience of the game.\nIf you are comparing this game to classics like FFT, Front Mission, or other strategy-jrpgs, you may be disappointed as Agarest is not trying to be the greatest game ever.  And you know what, that is okay, it satisfies an itch of wanting to play jrpgs on PC, and because of that, it's a pretty decent game.  Nothing special but games don't have to be special to be great.  Give it a try when it goes on sale.

reviewText:
Summary
-Not the best starting game for JRPG newbies
-Experienced JRPG should enjoy this game
-Hard to get into at first but you will love the story once you get it
-Be prepared to spend a long time completing the game (at least 100+ hours)
-Already worth the money just from the game length

Notes
I am writing as a person who had never played any form of RPG games before. I have also only completed the second generation as of the time of review, I usually write reviews after i'm done with the game but I felt like I had to get this off my chest.

Storyline The main storyline for this game isn't the most interesting one. Its about a person and his decendants becoming a medium to seal off the forces of darkness. The more interesting bit of the story comes from the individual stories told by the heroes in every generation, in another words there should be 5 stories to play through since i believe there are 5 generations of heroes to play. So far in the first and second generation, the beginning wasn't very interesting since nothing much happens, but when complications in the story arises, it becomes more enjoyable to read and play. My biggest complaint about the story is that it seems certain 'events' can only be triggered when you follow the 'true ending', which is difficult to achieve without a walkthrough. I hope that in Agarest: Generations of War 2, all of the 'events' will be readily available as the story progresses.

GameplayAs a complete newbie in JRPGs, Agarest lacks of help features that can really make a person quit after an hour. The mechanics of the game is more complicated than MMOs whereby setting up combos is required to win the game. While the tutorial is helpful in explaining the mechanics and only teaches you what you need to know at that time, there is a lack of help or FAQ to refer to anytime in game in case of any doubts. Due to that, after taking a long break from the game, I struggled on the mechanics of the game for awhile before getting the hang of it.

Another personal issue that I had with this game is the fact that it is too long, there are cases where I had to fight through up to 4-5 stages of monsters before i can trigger another 'event'. This makes the game feel very tiring because alot of time needs to be spent before the story can progress. I really hope that future generations and Agarest: Generations of war 2 will have shorter stages in between 'events' to make the game less tiring to play.

On the plus side, because the game is abit hard, it really calls for proper strategic plays to win and minimise losses and that is something I enjoy. The skills in the game is also very flashy which I like as well although it would be nice to have a 'normal' attack so that I could save ap for future use and not waste it on a 50hp enemy.

Conclusion
People who are new to this genre might want to stay away from this game and try something else first to get a good gist on how a JRPG feels like. Those who already played JRPGs before should definitely try this game out. In my opinion the price tag of $15 is already enough to keep you playing for at least a month or so.

reviewText:
Give not only yourself to your country but also your sons.

This is a great strategy JRPG game with a great storyline that span across generations of the main character. Combat with a new approach through the linking system allowing slower teammates to link up with faster teammates in order to perform their attacks or combination attacks quicker.

During the adventure from each generation, your character will be able to build relationship with 3 different female characters through selections of responses. At the end of the generation, if they have positive affection towards you, you can choose one of the 3 to be your wife. Your son's stats will be different depending who you choose and he will continue the story in the next generation. Old teammates from previous generation will also return to aid you in the new adventure.

So far some of the flaws is the crafting system, which some of the materials requires you to overkill certain enemies in order to get and if you missed a key enemies that cannot be fought in the current generation then that is it. Combats can get repetitive after a while since you are basically tasked to fight until the next diaglog or an event. Also hit accuracy since Leo loves to miss his attacks even from behind the enemies.

reviewText:
So, I've been trying to think of a way to review this that doesn't start with that I feel like an idiot.

Look what happened there! :D

But seriously. The first time I saw this was on the PlayStation Store, and after some reading and seeing the 360's Really Naughty Limited Edition, I kind of laughed it off and went on my way. I missed out. Thankfully, it's come to the Steam store for PC! :D And I have had the opportunity to play it at significantly less than the asking price for the consoles.

The story isn't a shining example of originality, but it gets the job done and it has some laughs to keep you smiling given you subscribe to this game's type of humour. You are Leonhardt, a former general of the Gridamas army and you sell your soul and the soul of your son, grandson, great grandson and great great grandson in exchange for life and the power to defeat the evil sweeping the land! So the game has strategy gameplay AND a dating sim, as at the end of each generation you will need to choose a bride with which to produce the next generation's hero. The strengths of that future hero are dependent on which bride you chose and your affection level with her.

The gameplay itself, is pretty standard for a turn based strategy RPG, which is both good and bad. The good is that it isn't particularly esoteric as some strategy games tend to be. You needn't read the internet or page through a thick manual to be able to play this. You can pick it up and be on your way in about 15 minutes of tutorials if you read fast. It uses the standard five core stats, with resistances and so on. If you've played almost any RPG before this, there are no surprises here.

The BAD is that the combat has nothing that really makes it uniquely Agarest, and it almost never seems to deviate from the same formula. Most battles can be approached by making the same set of actions to get the exact same extension squares from one battle to the next, and I have done so quite successfully in the First Generation. So, the combat can get a bit repetative but for those that don't mind grinding, that isn't a big deal.

The art is kind of questionable. More effort was put into the environments and the drawings used for conversations than into game character sprites. I feel like so much more could have been done to enhance the characters' visual identity and they just... didn't. That being said, the environents are beautifully detailed on the PC and the manga style art for the conversations is beautiful and entertaining to watch. The dialogue can often be quite funny, too!

Overall, I'd give this a 7/10. It is definitely worth the dollar amount in entertainment value.

reviewText: If you're looking for a game that'll take you well over 100 hours, then look no further! Record of Agarest War (or Agarest: Generations of War) is a tactical RPG waifu simulator. It spans over 5 generations, each which takes at least 10 hours to complete. It's got a pretty decent story, a good combat system, and good character designs. However, I will give some fair warnings. Auto battle is worthless unless you are uber leveled, The AI piles all of your characters' attacks on one enemy, and is super inefficient. Some parts can be a slog, the story is good and interesting, but some points have much larger gaps in actual story conent than others. I.e. Sometimes it takes 2 battles between a story point, other times it's  10+ battles per story point. Overall it's a great game, but with a few flaws.

reviewText:
This is my first review of any game. Just saying. HOWEVER, Agarest deserves my review, even if my critique skills are poor.
If you read this, please read it through. :3

What even is this game?
Agarest: Generations of War is a turn-based RPG, using a system of tiles as a playing field, where your characters can move and attack opposing enemies. Simple, right? Kind of. (we'll get into that later). But, for now, realize that this game is a turn-based RPG with a visual-novel story-telling method and a TON of stats to consider. (which I love).

Story
The story in this game is interesting. I like it because of it's simplicity, yet there are mysteries to solve (if you pay attention) and lore to uncover. It takes place in a magical land where Humans and other various species (like Elves) are at war. There is a backstory about light and dark, and dark lords and such, but you read that in the beginning of the game, so you can do that.

Overall, it's not a bad story. However, since I haven't finished the game, I cannot give a complete answer. Howver so far it takes my interest.

Characters
Each character in this game is unique in their own ways (which is a must for RPG's, and any game for that matter). So far, I feel no emotional" attatchment to any of them

reviewText:
TL;DR: Agarest: Generations of War is a turnbased/gridbased JRPG with very minor dating sim elements to it. It probably has nothing you haven't seen done before in the 6 years that it's been out. If you're really into JRPGs or on a quest to marry as many imaginary elves as possible in your lifetime, you'll probably want to check this game out.

JRPG is a genre that generally relies heavily on clichés and Agarest: Generations of War is no exception; the game is set in a standard Japanese fantasy setting with obligatory elves and you are the chosen one, destined to save the world! If you can't stand cheesy fiction, then stay far away from this title; it is one of the 5 legendary cheese generals of the legendary cheese army of legend.

The gameplay consist mainly of 3 things:
1. The overworld map where you walk from place to place and visit towns where you can upgrade equipment/trade/craft items/etc.
2. The visual novel style story segments.
3. The main meat of the game, the battle system. Battles are played out on a gridbased plane. The key part of the gameplay is linking together characters(if characters stand in certain spots relative to their teammates position, they become linked) thus enabling them to attack at the same time and do combo attacks. Part of the charm of JRPGs is to watch ridiculous super-attacks play out.

Now, there are a few things I found unique about this game. (!!NOT REALLY SPOILERS, YOU GET TO KNOW THIS AFTER THE FIRST FIGHT!!) The way the story plays out is that you die, and have the option to be ressurected, but only in exchange for devoting your life, and the lives of your children, to defeating the great evil that's coming. Generations of War". A threat too powerful for one single generation to beat? Cool.

You should know that the game is spoken entirely in Japanese. I love it
date: but there's a lot people who dislike it being in Japanese only

reviewText:
At first glance Agarest: Generations of War may seem like a really interesting and immersing tactical RPG having a seemingly intricate battle system. However it is the battle system that is used that largely hinders the game. Comboing is repetative and tedious and requires you to position your characters in ways that often compromises tactics, occasionally you'll have to turn your back to an enemy just to link with a character.

Another issue out of battle is the grind, everything in this game is crafted or gotten from drops. The shops are pretty much useless because until you craft something the shops won't stock it. This goes for skills, weapons, etc. There is a monster raising aspect to the game aswel but the battles are far too boring to want to catch monsters. I find myself only able to play this game in short bursts and after 10 hours started using the DLC gear just to speed up the agonizing process.

The story is relatively bland although I find it and the generations system the only real thing that kept me playing this game. The dialogue is often completely terrible and the background scenery is recycled countless times even when on different continents. Additionally there are next to cinematics in this game except the occasional bedroom" scene which is little less than fanservice.

In sum I reccomend you NOT play this game even if you enjoy the genre this game is not a good port."

reviewText: It's a terrible game for terrible dudes. The story is cliche and the the gameplay is entirely too repetitive. It's nothing more than the same battle after battle. And the story isn't interesting enough to feel like a reward. I've tried playing this on console and PC. I tried again on PC solely because it was on sale with booster packs, so I thought maybe I could get through the game without the grindfest. But now I remember why I dropped the game in the first place. It wasn't that it was a grindfest. It was because the story was not engaging, nor was the gameplay. No doubt, the battle mechanics are interesting with how duel attacks and special attacks are forged between various characters on the board. But at the end of the day, I really think the fact that ALL battle boards are FLAT with NO terrain variation kills the game. Final Fantasy Tactics in 1998 had terrain variation. This game from the 21st century does not. Perhaps if it was on NES I could excuse it. But this transgression is not excusable for modern games.

reviewText:
2 Stars - A slice of JRPG culture that may not appeal to new entrants to this style.

Although the game trys to build on  a strong platform of coordinated tactical battles and gripping Japanese story telling I found this game missed the mark.

I am not a regular in the JRPG arena and I found this game to be a slugging grindfest. Repititive tatical battles are often duplicated and unengaging. The base game comes with a level of DLC type content which should mean that a small portion of your party is over powered from the start while the rest are left looking weak and fragile. So I added additional DLC weapons and found my OP party stuck grinding pixies in a forest.

There are other aspects to this game (crafting, battle pets, etc) but these only slowed the game down further. Overall if you not sure this is the game for you it proabably isn't.

Pros -
Anime / Story

Cons -
Grinding
Poor DLC mix
Graphics
Repititive

reviewText:
Agarest: Generations of War feels like a clumsy, watered-down Disgaea clone. This isn't terrible because it has streamlined the experince quite a bit, but it some aspects have been simplified too much.

Pros:
-Good special and combo attack system.
-Tutorial sequence is far better than most other games in the genre.
-Graphics are nice.
-Voices are in Japanese rather than a low-budget dub.
-Story isn't cringe-inducing.

Cons:
-The battles are too small to be very interesting with the system this game has.
-Giving the player 10,000 gold is not DLC.
-An awkward translation sometimes interferes with gameplay.
-The story often feels disjointed. I don't know if this is the translation's fault or not.

Verdict:
If you like tactical RPGs, then go ahead and get this if it's on sale. Otherwise stay away.

reviewText:
Short: The combat suuucks!

Long:
The character's are interesting and the story is engaging, but the combat absolutely kills it. I kept wanting to go back but couldn't stand more than one or two fights before giving up and moving on.

It uses a grid movement system on top of regular combat necessitating battle formations and allowing characters to move earlier if they're in certain position in relation to each other, which may not sound all that bad, but after a while it just turns into a dull slog of move-organise attacks-move. A classic battle set-up with each team staying on opposite sides of a field would have been bearable but splicing chess into it just kills the pacing.

Oh sure, it's fun to see my guys team up on some poor monster and execute an over-the-top attack combo dealing twice it's health in damage, but that would still be present if they'd gone for a traditional battlefield setup. And the paths you follow force you to go through so many battles between each story part, meaning you can't avoid it.

I don't normally mind if a game has a rather slow pace. In the past I've spent 80+ hours on single play-throughs of Dragon Age, but unavoidable, brow-beatingly dull combat made it seem more like a job than a game. Hell, there's enough story here to just make it a visual novel and scrap the combat completely.

While I would have liked to see it through to completion, I've sadly put it in my Ignored list simply because I couldn't find the enthusiasim to keep dragging on have since moved to more engaging titles. Kudos to anyone that finished it.

reviewText:
First and foremost, this is very much a niche game, it is not for everyone. What really drew me in to playing so much of the game, doing two playthroughs, was the combat system. At it's core, Agarest GoW is a tactical turn based strategy RPG, and it does that very well. Combat is interesting, complex, and full of depth. It isn't perfect though, each battle can last for several minutes due to a few factors. First being archaic pre-determined load times of battles, you can have GoW on a SSD, have it load in miliseconds, yet all the battles take 30 seconds to load the enemies and players. Combat animations can be skipped, which helps, but it still doesn't speed up the process of setting up your attacks, which is fun, but time consuming.

Story wise, GoW has a great, and very long main story. With any of the DLC weapons to get through the early generations quickly, you are looking at a 125+ hour story, and without them, it could easly be 150+ hours, before you get to the final boss. The story is an epic tale of a world slowly being consumed by darkness, and you fight, literally for over 100 years, to save the world, which is slowly being taken over by demon armies. Most of the characters are very interesting, and have their own unique personalities and motivations. You really do get a feeling that you know who a character is, and why they are there, it just might take some time to flesh out a character. Oh, and there are a lot of playable characters, 30+ in fact, from all the generations, not including nearly every enemy in the game which can be turned into a party member if you choose to do so. You really do have a large variety of characters and skill sets to choose from, and each generation change always forces you to change up your party members and play style in some way.

One other issue I had was that in order to get the most out of seeing all the events and experiencing the game, you need to play through the perfect path. Pre-post game stuff, as well as the full post game doesn't even unlock unless you follow a very specific set path of choices throughout the game. If you want the most out of the game, you really do need to follow a perfect path guide.

What made me kept playing was simply how much fun the combat was, up until post-game, the combat was very diverse and interesting. Post-game however really devolves into a cheese fest where you use the cheeziest stratigies in order to beat bosses. Who would think you can kill gods, dragons, demons, devils, and all sorts of mythical creatures using grass as your primary weapon.

One last note about the DLC, the weapons are powerful, some of which are nearly as powerful as the strongest weapons in the game. They really do save a lot of time though, because let's face it, there is a lot of grinding for things. Even with powerful weapons, in generation 3 and beyond you can easily die to bosses if you aren't careful.

If you are a fan of Strategy RPG's, love a good story, and don't mind putting 125+ hours into a game, Agarest Generations of War is for you.

reviewText:
Okay so, like, this game's got it all right? It's got stratagy for those who love stratagy. It's got a dating sim for those who love to pillage the fertile land of women, and then it's got REPLAYABILITY like no other game I've ever seen.

Let me stress the most important part of this game; it's replayability.
It has 99 save slots for a reason. USE THEM, or you will be restarting all over constantly.
(Of course, the First generation isn't that bad as I can speed rush it in around 3 hours on hard, without any of those OP DLC)
Because of the dating simulation part of this game, it makes you, like PHYSICALLY MAKES YOU, retry over and over to get the woman you want. Of course, this isn't just preference. The woman you pick each generation has a lasting effect through the entire game, making it extremely crucial to save a lot. As some women will give you the weapons and stats you want, as others will not. It depends on how you play the game though, and want to.
Luckily, the first generation is pretty set-in-stone in terms of who you marry and what your son will be like, but after that, your decisions and how you play the game affect their stats even more drastically. They could be a mage who likes to use daggers, or a pathetically low-health ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ who can't do anything worth a damn.
This game also has a nice sneak-preview feature that allows you to see how the women your courting will affect your son, so you can manipulate it to an extent.
And if you mess up, you have to start over. All. Over. Again.

That's just the DATING SIM part of it, which is actually a lot of this game, but meh.

The replayability comes as an offset of the Dating Sim, as you have to replay this game Quite a Bit to have all the sons and all of their possible stat outcomes, along with all the possible lineage. Around a lot of times, if I did my math right.

Also the story is pretty interesting, I mean, who wouldn't want to be part of a Four-some every generation? I mean, come on, insta TAKE MY MONEY" game.

This game also comes with a lot of DLC

reviewText:
I cannot place this into a yes or no choice. As everyone is subjective in what they think is good or bad, great or terrible. Either way I can only share my thoughts and experiences with the game and nothing more.

Length:
The game is long and not because of story reasons. The navigation between place to place is annoying and eventually becomes repeitive and feels almost grindy in the aspect of progressing the story. Sometimes you'll have an event placed on the map while you're progressing that is brief dialogue, sometimes a choice that causes an effect on someones affections. (I will touch up on this later.) So far I've placed almost 30 hours into the game I have yet to finish the second generation story because of the reasons above. I find it more tedious moving across the map fighting almost the same fights over and over.

Story:
So far it does well to develop itself at the start but sometimes it feels like it becomes shallow and doesn't do much to progress itself effectively. Sometimes a new character can appear from left field without any warning with a vague explination for their part in the story. In terms of character development it doesn't feel right and some characters don't have any real defining points especially when they feel flat in terms of the heroines, specifically the first generation. The main hero also comes off just as flat and doesn't feel like he can leave a lasting impression. Except for Winfield... the guy just wins so hard that he is my favorite character so far. There is also a light, dark and neutral alignments, and given how far I am, I have yet to see any changes to story.

Without going into too much detail the game is in five parts, each with its own main hero and set of lovely ladies to marry and have a child with. It has a lot of potential of what you could do with the hero in each generation. The chocies are small at first but once you reach into the third and fourth generations the combinations are MASSIVE. Affection shows you how well your next hero will be as the more they love the hero, the stronger the stats the hero will have going into the next generation. Their weapon, stats, skills and appearence are determined by his mother, grandmother, great grandmother and great, great grandmother.

For what it is worth there are a lot of profiles and CG pictures you can unlock depending on your in game choices and fullfilling certain requirments. So if you're a completionist better buckle down, grab your cheetoes and Mtn Dew and get cracking.

Combat:
Broken down into two phases as 'movement phase' and 'combat phase'. At first it feels odd to get used to at first but later becomes easier as you progress. Every action and movement you do is dictated by AP. What AP does for you is provide you with actions in combat for various skills and combination attacks you can do. Moving a space costs one AP. Various magic, healing, and attack spells cost anywhere from 8-24 depending on what it is. During the movement phase who moves is determined by the agility stat. Which honestly isn't that great given its whoever has the most AP in the combat phase that can act first really goes against the stat in terms of affecting turn flow.

Every player has an extended zone which affects various tiles on the map. Anyone standing on those tiles is linked with that player allowing them to act sooner, join in on combo attacks, and get them out of harms way, or in it if you do some... questionable things like I have.

Advancement:
There are several things you have to do improve your armor, weapons, skills and items. It is dependant on gathering materials, creating the item which then unlocks in the shops for purchase later. Sometimes this can become tedious as you'll have problems getting a monster drop or the creater will goof up and give you something better, which is awesome, or worse, with is a setback depending on what you were making.

The game also invokes its inner Shin Megami Tensei by letting you capture monsters you encounter on the map and use them to fight, combine or trade them in for items, weapons and armor.

Appearance and Sound:
The game for what its worth does look visually georgous to look at and reminds me of Disgaea. Depending on the specs of your computer you can have some slowdown besides the already sluggish feel of the game, which can be fixed by adjusting the FPS to about 40-45 in the folder's .ini.

Overall:
The game isn't too bad. Its just steep in terms of what you have to do. While the game can be cleared with almost no equipment, items and stragegy it does test the patience of the player. If you don't mind the slow drudge it places on you from its inate FPS, repetiive combat, tedious map navigations and RNG based monster drop farming this game is for you. If it sounds like a turn off and you're unsure give the game a try.  I give Agarest: Generations of War a 7/10

At best I can't tell you not to buy this game or stay away and can only provide you what I've encountered with and the problems I've seen with it. If you pick this up use the DLC content that is provided to you from buying the game if yo uwant to experience the game the way it is meant to be. The weapons are really broken and cheese the game too hard.

reviewText: Much better than I expected! I went into this thinking it might be alright but the storyline, gameplay, and even the graphics were all brilliant. Keep in mind I have not completed the game yet but this storyline managed to keep my attention for hours on end with every twist or possible light/dark decision. Unlike most games where saying one thing or another adds a few points to a stat, or maybe makes your character look different. Any light/dark choice made in Agarest can result in major path changes, not to mention how characters will view you in the long run of things. Which means each playthrough can be a unique depending on the choices you make. Aside from the great RPG elements taking a look at the graphics alone makes me go from viewing great anime style portraits for discussions, to looking at well detailed character pieces during battles with full animation. Along with the costumization of which each weapon has it's own unqiue look when used in combat which means not only might you like the stats of a said weapon, it might look really cool in use as well. Even the minor aspects of the game such as adventure were well placed having certain areas which are close to the style of a dungeon crawler. The actual gameplay made sure I never got bored though. When it comes to battle each character is different, and the system is so in depth about how to chain together skills that I actually wanted to read the tutorials so I could pull off some insane combos. The strategy aspect of this game really shines in its combat.\n\nI don't know how this game got such a low metascore, I personally give it a 9/10. I highly recommend this game to anyone who enjoys RPGs and strategy, not to mention anyone who enjoys a good storyline.

reviewText:
Do yourself a favour and avoid this game. Everything it attempts to do has already been done in a more elegant and satisfying way by other games.

I found the SRPG combat to be boring—boring, that is, unless you forget to turn off the DLC included in the game, which grants you a full set of end-game gear that is so overpowering as to make combat completely trivial. The Final Fantasy Tactics, Fire Emblem, Disgaea or Super Robot Wars games all offer a much more satisfying experience.

While the setup for the plot is good—it's the same that Code Geass had, and that turned out great—the writing is terrible. The main character is shown as a bleeding-heart sentimentalist who deserts from his very first battle and latches hard onto a random elf girl, not just saving her but putting a spur-of-the-moment promise to protect her above his life (hell, above his soul). Every time dialogue scenes came up I had the unpleasant, immersion-breaking feeling of real people wouldn't say or do this." For a SRPG with good writing pick up the remake of Final Fantasy Tactics for iOS or Disgaea.

You like the ability to choose your own heroine? Der Langrisser (get it for a SNES emulator) did this back in the 90s along with branching plotlines

reviewText:
First off, be aware that I have used some fixes as posted on the forums and this has returned the game much more polished-particularly the FPS increase. In it's native form there were some technical glitches.

Ok, so it;s a fairly simple premise:fight lots, kill stuff and save the world. However, the fact that you do this over 5 generations of the same bloodline makes it replayable even before you have finished it. And even when you get there, you may want to go back and do it again to see what you missed.

This is the beauty of the game-it reminded me of FF7 in that respect. I remember killing the last boss and realising I had a lot more to do. This game is full of little extras like that which keep you hooked. So, the admittedly linear timeline doesn''t detract from the final product. The inclusion of titles (gotta get them all), crafting to make better gear and even skills make for a varied and enjoyable experience.

This game IS kind of grindy, but only if you want to get everything. The combat is fluid and the combo system works really well. there's a real feeling of satisfaction when you wait for a while building up energy before that final apocalypse when you unleash the fury of the heavens.

So, the positives are: lots of character customisation, absolutely loads to do, and it certainly delivers on value for money. There are negatives, like the tutorial always playing when you start a new game, the inconvenience of having to fix the FPS lock, but these are minor issues.

If you want a fighting, crafting, collecting, exploring and story-driven RPG, Agarest could well be for you.

reviewText: This game is decently entertaining if you can tolerate the silly and tame story the game has. It's a bit of an anime-ish take on a lord of the rings esque epic that spans over several generations with your character needing to have an heir to follow in their footsteps. Fun characters, unique design and great looking 2d isometric strategy battles give it a nice asthetic appeal, however the game has some counter intuitive mechanics with the turn system, extremely long and sort of overly complex battles, and of course the story with its trial and error guessing game on how to convince your female companions to like you enough to do the deed.\n\nAll in all it feels like the game doesnt do anything in particular very well and the boring battles make it a difficult buy. Still if you like JRPGs, have patience, and love strategy Rpgs, then this might tide you over to get youre fire emblem/tactics/suikoden fix. :)

reviewText:
Agarest: Generations of War feels like a clumsy, watered-down Disgaea clone. This isn't terrible because it has streamlined the experince quite a bit, but it some aspects have been simplified too much.

Pros:
-Good special and combo attack system.
-Tutorial sequence is far better than most other games in the genre.
-Graphics are nice.
-Voices are in Japanese rather than a low-budget dub.
-Story isn't cringe-inducing.

Cons:
-The battles are too small to be very interesting with the system this game has.
-Giving the player 10,000 gold is not DLC.
-An awkward translation sometimes interferes with gameplay.
-The story often feels disjointed. I don't know if this is the translation's fault or not.

Verdict:
If you like tactical RPGs, then go ahead and get this if it's on sale. Otherwise stay away.

reviewText:
Short: The combat suuucks!

Long:
The character's are interesting and the story is engaging, but the combat absolutely kills it. I kept wanting to go back but couldn't stand more than one or two fights before giving up and moving on.

It uses a grid movement system on top of regular combat necessitating battle formations and allowing characters to move earlier if they're in certain position in relation to each other, which may not sound all that bad, but after a while it just turns into a dull slog of move-organise attacks-move. A classic battle set-up with each team staying on opposite sides of a field would have been bearable but splicing chess into it just kills the pacing.

Oh sure, it's fun to see my guys team up on some poor monster and execute an over-the-top attack combo dealing twice it's health in damage, but that would still be present if they'd gone for a traditional battlefield setup. And the paths you follow force you to go through so many battles between each story part, meaning you can't avoid it.

I don't normally mind if a game has a rather slow pace. In the past I've spent 80+ hours on single play-throughs of Dragon Age, but unavoidable, brow-beatingly dull combat made it seem more like a job than a game. Hell, there's enough story here to just make it a visual novel and scrap the combat completely.

While I would have liked to see it through to completion, I've sadly put it in my Ignored list simply because I couldn't find the enthusiasim to keep dragging on have since moved to more engaging titles. Kudos to anyone that finished it.
